theme_passages.title: The Science Fair
theme_passages.text: Kayla worked on her science project for weeks. She tested her hypothesis over and over. The night before the fair, her display board fell and broke. Instead of giving up, Kayla stayed up late to fix it. She didn't win first place, but the judges praised her determination. Kayla learned that success isn't always about winningâ€”it's about not giving up.
theme_passages.theme: Perseverance is more important than winning
evidence: stayed up late to fix it

theme_passages.title: The New Kid
theme_passages.text: Nobody talked to Omar on his first day. He sat alone at lunch feeling invisible. Then he noticed another boy sitting alone too. Omar walked over and introduced himself. Soon they were laughing about their favorite video games. By the end of the week, their lunch table had five kids.
theme_passages.theme: Taking initiative can lead to unexpected friendships
evidence: Omar walked over and introduced himself
their lunch table had five kids

theme_passages.title: The Team Captain
theme_passages.text: As team captain, Destiny always picked the best players first. Her team won most games, but the same kids always got picked last. One day, she picked them first instead. The team didn't win, but everyone played hard and had fun. Destiny realized being a leader means making sure everyone feels included.
theme_passages.theme: True leadership is about inclusion, not just winning
evidence: everyone played hard and had fun

passages_to_summarize.text: The Amazon rainforest is one of the most important ecosystems on Earth. It produces about 20% of the world's oxygen and is home to millions of species of plants and animals. Many medicines come from plants found only in the Amazon. However, the rainforest is in danger due to deforestation. People cut down trees for farming and building. Scientists warn that we must protect the Amazon to keep our planet healthy.
passages_to_summarize.sample_summary: The Amazon rainforest is vital to Earth because it produces oxygen, houses millions of species, and provides medicines. However, it is threatened by deforestation, and scientists say we must protect it.

passages_to_summarize.text: Rosa Parks was an African American woman who helped change history. In 1955, she refused to give up her bus seat to a white passenger in Montgomery, Alabama. At that time, Black people were forced to sit in the back of buses. Rosa was arrested for her brave act. Her arrest led to the Montgomery Bus Boycott, where Black citizens refused to ride buses for over a year. This protest helped end segregation on public buses.
key_points: Rosa Parks refused to give up bus seat
passages_to_summarize.sample_summary: In 1955, Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat and was arrested. This led to the Montgomery Bus Boycott, which helped end segregation on public buses.

passages.text: Bees are essential to our food supply. They pollinate about 75% of the fruits and vegetables we eat. Without bees, we would lose apples, almonds, blueberries, and many other foods. Sadly, bee populations are declining due to pesticides, habitat loss, and disease. Farmers and scientists are working together to protect bees by planting wildflowers and reducing harmful chemicals.
passages.main_idea: Bees are essential to our food supply and need protection
supporting_details: populations declining due to pesticides and habitat loss

passages.text: Getting enough sleep is crucial for students. Sleep helps the brain store what you learned during the day. Without enough sleep, it's harder to focus and remember things. Studies show that students who sleep 8-10 hours perform better on tests. To improve sleep, experts suggest avoiding screens before bed and keeping a regular sleep schedule.
passages.main_idea: Sleep is crucial for student success

fluency_passages.text: The old lighthouse stood on the rocky cliff, its beam cutting through the foggy night. Captain Wells had sailed these waters for thirty years, and he knew every rock, every current. Tonight, though, something felt different. The wind whispered warnings, and the waves seemed to push his boat away from shore. He trusted the lighthouse to guide him home, just as it had countless times before.

Scientists have discovered that octopuses are incredibly intelligent creatures. They can solve puzzles, open jars, and even recognize individual human faces. In one famous experiment, an octopus learned to turn off a light by squirting water at the bulb. These amazing animals have three hearts, blue blood, and can change color in less than a second to camouflage themselves.
